The kernel uses a 1D grid configuration to maximize parallelism and GPU occupancy.
The kernel avoids loops and conditionals within the thread code to minimize instruction overhead.
The kernel leverages broadcast memory access for repeated reads of the same value across threads in a warp.
The kernel uses a grid size calculated to ensure sufficient blocks for high occupancy, particularly for large problem sizes.
The kernel accesses global memory in a coalesced manner when problem dimensions align with block size.
The kernel avoids synchronization primitives and shared memory usage to reduce overhead.
The kernel processes elements per thread without vectorization, simplifying memory access patterns.
